content: The Act may be cited as the "Appalachian Regional Development Act Amendments of 2002" and its purpose is outlined in Section 2. The "Appalachian Regional Development Act Amendments of 2002" aims to reauthorize the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 and ensure that the Appalachian region has access to telecommunication and technology services to compete in the knowledge-based economy of the United States. Amendments include promoting eco-industrial development for employment, economic growth, and natural resource preservation. The "Appalachian Regional Development Act Amendments of 2002" aim to reauthorize the Act of 1965 and promote eco-industrial development technologies for economic growth and resource preservation. SEC. 3 of the Appalachian Regional Development Act Amendments of 2002 expands the functions of the Commission to include encouraging eco-industrial development technologies and coordinating economic development activities among Federal agencies in the region. SEC. 4 amends the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 to establish the Interagency Coordinating Council on Appalachia, with a focus on economic development programs in the region. SEC. 5 amends the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 to include a new section on Telecommunications and Technology Initiative. The Commission may provide technical assistance, grants, contracts, or funds for projects to increase affordable access to advanced telecommunications, provide education and training in technology, develop e-commerce readiness programs, and support entrepreneurial opportunities in the information technology sector. Funding for assistance may come from amounts allocated for this purpose. The Commission may provide technical assistance, grants, contracts, or funds for projects to increase affordable access to advanced telecommunications, education, e-commerce readiness programs, and support entrepreneurial opportunities in the information technology sector. Funding for assistance may come from amounts allocated for this purpose, either exclusively or in combination with funds from other sources. The Federal share requirements specified in other laws can be increased using funds from this section. Cost sharing for grants is limited to 50 percent of costs, or 80 percent in distressed counties. SEC. 6. ENTREPRENEURSHIP INITIATIVE. Title II of the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 is amended to include a new section, "SEC. 204. ENTREPRENEURSHIP INITIATIVE." This initiative aims to support entrepreneurial opportunities in the information technology sector. The term 'business incubator service' refers to professional or technical services needed for new businesses, including legal services, intellectual property protection, technology acquisition, and strategic consultation. The Commission may provide assistance, grants, contracts, or funds for projects in the region. The Commission may provide funds for projects supporting entrepreneurial training, improving access to capital, aiding communities in development strategies, establishing business incubators, and supporting entities providing incubator services. Funding may come from allocated amounts for this purpose. The Commission may provide funds for projects supporting entrepreneurial training, improving access to capital, aiding communities in development strategies, establishing business incubators, and supporting entities providing incubator services. Funding may come from allocated amounts for this purpose, with federal share requirements specified in other laws. The cost sharing for grants is limited to not more than 50 percent of the costs, or 80 percent in distressed counties. SEC. 205. REGIONAL SKILLS PARTNERSHIPS. This section is added to Title II of the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965, focusing on establishing partnerships for regional skills development. The section defines an "eligible entity" as a consortium serving industries in a specific area, consisting of representatives from businesses, labor organizations, governments, and educational institutions. The Commission can provide assistance to these entities for projects improving job skills, including training assessments, curriculum development, and technology integration. The eligible entity can use funds for training programs, apprenticeship development, and partnerships with educational institutions. Administrative costs are limited to 10% of the funds. Funding for assistance can come from allocated amounts. The eligible entity can use funds for training programs, apprenticeship development, and partnerships with educational institutions. Administrative costs are limited to 10% of the funds. Funding for assistance can come from allocated amounts. The Federal share requirements specified in other laws can be increased using funds from this section. Cost sharing for grants is capped at 50% of costs, or 80% in distressed counties. SEC. 8. PROGRAM DEVELOPMENT CRITERIA. (a) Elimination of Growth Center Criteria.--Section 224(a)(1) of the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 is amended by removing the criteria for significant growth potential in an area determined by the State. (b) Assistance to Distressed Counties and Areas.--Section 224 is amended to allocate at least 50 percent of grant expenditures to benefit severely distressed counties and areas. SEC. 9. GRANTS FOR ADMINISTRATIVE EXPENSES OF LOCAL DEVELOPMENT DISTRICTS. Section 302(a)(1)(A)(i) of the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 is amended to include provisions for administrative expenses of local development districts. Section 302(a)(1)(A)(i) of the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 is amended to allow for 75 percent of expenses for local development districts with a charter or authority focused on economic development in distressed counties. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Amendment to Section 401 of the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 for authorization of appropriations. SEC. 401 authorizes appropriations for the Appalachian development highway system program, with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 2002 through 2006. Additionally, funds are designated for the Telecommunications and Technology Initiative. The allocated sums remain available until expended. SEC. 11 of the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 is amended to add counties to the Appalachian region in Kentucky and Mississippi. SEC. 12 changes the termination date to 2006. SEC. 13 includes technical and conforming amendments. The Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 is amended to change terminology, remove expiration dates, and make technical adjustments to grant programs. The Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 is amended to update terminology and make technical adjustments to grant programs under various Acts. The Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 is amended to update terminology and make technical adjustments to grant programs under various Acts. The amendments include changing references to "grant-in-aid Act" to simply "Act," updating terminology related to grant programs, and defining the term "Federal grant program" to encompass various assistance activities. The term 'Federal grant program' in this section includes various Federal grant programs authorized by Acts such as the Consolidated Farm and Rural Development Act, Land and Water Conservation Fund Act, Watershed Protection and Flood Prevention Act, Carl D. Perkins Vocational and Technical Education Act, Federal Water Pollution Control Act, Public Health Service Act, and Public Works and Economic Development Act. In this section, the term 'Federal grant program' excludes certain programs such as the Appalachian development highway system and highway construction programs authorized by specific Acts. Subsection (d) is also removed. Additionally, Section 224(a)(2) of the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 is amended to replace "relative per capita income" with "per capita market income." Section 225 of the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965 is amended to replace "development program" with "development strategies" in subsection (a)(3) and "development programs" with "development strategies" in subsection (c)(2). Section 303 is also amended to replace "investment programs" with "strategy statements" in the section heading and throughout the text. In the Appalachian Regional Development Act of 1965, Section 403 is amended to change the reference from "Committee on Public Works and Transportation" to "Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure".
